awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology: An ecophysiological examination of the role of parasite interactions in mediating emerging fungal disease in snakes
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY2022, Broadening Participation of Groups Underrepresented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. Wild animals are frequently infected by multiple parasitic organisms simultaneously. Studies of warm-blooded animals (endotherms) – mammals and birds show that interactions between coinfecting parasites can have profound impacts on the ability to combat disease. For example, parasitic worms (macroparasites) often dampen immune responses, thereby, facilitating infection and disease caused by pathogenic viruses, bacteria, and fungi (microparasites). This phenomenon is known as the “macro-micro facilitation hypothesis.” Despite the common occurrence of parasitic coinfections in wild cold-blooded animals (ectotherms) – fish, amphibians, and reptiles, little is known about the interactions between macro- and microparasites in these animals and how these influence ectotherm physiology (such as the immune response) and disease outcome. This research will be one of few studies to evaluate the mechanisms underlying macro-micro facilitation in an ectothermic animal. By advancing understanding about how interactions between coinfecting parasites shape ectotherm disease ecology, this research will provide new insights for ectotherm conservation in a changing world. The Fellow will design and implement educational activities and will create resources and research opportunities to promote the inclusion and success of middle school and college students underrepresented in biology. 

This research will use field surveys, laboratory analyses, and advanced statistical modeling to test the macro–micro facilitation hypothesis in wild snakes focusing on the fungal microparasite Ophidiomyces ophiodiicola, which causes the recently emerged skin disease ophidiomycosis. While the threat of ophidiomycosis to snake biodiversity remains unclear, sublethal impacts may have substantial consequences for population health and stability. The Fellow will describe how parasitic worm infections, O. ophiodiicola infections, and ophidiomycosis severity are correlated across multiple snake species and over time in one widespread snake species in eastern North America. The Fellow will then use structural equation modeling to identify and quantify the causal pathways that directly and indirectly link the many physiological, environmental, infection, and disease variables measured in wild snakes. The Fellow will participate in broadening the representation of underrepresented student in biology by 1) partnering with local outreach events to create activity kits and presentations focused on how environmental change influences snake health for fourth grade classrooms; 2) creating a social networking platform to connect and support foster care student populations at the host institution; 3) mentoring and providing independent research opportunities for undergraduate students through the host institution’s Applied Ecology Minor program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Wild animals are frequently infected by numerous parasitic organisms simultaneously. The impacts of these infections on wildlife immunity and disease susceptibility are unclear. Studies of mammals and birds suggest that infections by parasitic worms (macroparasites) can increase susceptibility to and disease symptoms caused by bacterial and fungal (microparasites) infections. It remains unknown whether such macro-micro facilitation applies to other animal groups. Given the rising prevalence of disease-causing fungal infections in cold-blooded animals, including snakes, addressing this knowledge gap is crucial for understanding how interactions between coinfecting parasites influence disease ecology and conservation in an increasingly changing world.

The NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology (PRFB) supported research on macro-micro facilitation in wild snakes, focusing on the widespread and abundant Nerodia water snakes. This research combined field, laboratory, and statistical methods to explore how macroparasite infections affect snake immunity, physiology, and responses to the emerging fungal parasite Ophidiomyces ophiodiicola (Oo), which causes ophidiomycosis. The fellow conducted 120 field visits surveying 87 wild snakes in North Carolina, and she established new collaborations with researchers at Stockton University and Texas State University to include samples from hundreds more water snakes from New Jersey and Texas. In all three regions, most snakes had fungal infections, but few showed signs of severe disease. The prevalence of internal parasitic worms, blood parasites, and metrics of immune function varied greatly between the three regions and between sites within regions, providing an ideal opportunity to explore how this variation impacts fungal disease. Data collection was conducted from August 2022 to July 2024 in Dr. Skylar Hopkins' lab at the North Carolina State University (NCSU) Department of Applied Ecology. The new collaborations tripled the size of the originally proposed project, so analyses of the data generated during the funding period are still in progress and are expected to result in four manuscripts that the fellow will lead or co-author within the next year.

Through her research at NCSU, the fellow gained proficiency in applying morphological, molecular, and statistical techniques to investigate complex questions in disease ecology. The fellow also integrated the training and mentorship of over ten undergraduate and graduate students, providing them with hands-on research experience in both laboratory and field settings. This mentorship led to the development of independent student projects, including investigating seasonal immune changes and characterizing blood parasite prevalence in water snakes, studies that contribute to a broader understanding of wildlife disease dynamics. The experiences enhanced the fellow’s expertise in animal physiology and immunity while strengthening her leadership and mentoring skills, fostering a collaborative research environment. This unique combination of research, mentorship, and professional development has positioned the fellow as a well-rounded professional, expanding her career opportunities and long-term impact as a scientist.

During the funding period, the fellow actively led and/or participated in outreach initiatives designed to increase the involvement of underrepresented groups in biology. As a volunteer scientist at three events hosted by the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, the fellow had the opportunity to engage with a broad audience, helping to share key concepts in parasitology and disease ecology. The museum events attracted over 11,000 visitors, providing the fellow with a platform to reach and interact with diverse individuals through informative and interactive displays. The fellow also developed and led hands-on activities focused on snake conservation and disease transmission for more than 90 middle school students as part of the North Carolina Science Festival's SciMatch for Middle Schools Program. Although the fellow was unable to create a social networking platform for foster students at NCSU due to limited technical resources, the fellow presented two research seminars to NCSU undergraduate and graduate students, where she shared her journey as a foster care student and mother in academia. The fellow also built professional connections with local nonprofit organizations, including SaySo and Youth Villages, which support underserved youth, including those in foster care. These relationships enabled the fellow to participate in several volunteer events, including the 2024 SaySo Saturday celebration and hosting a webinar on accessing financial resources for college and building resumes, furthering her commitment to community engagement and support for marginalized groups.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2024
Modified by: Kenzie E Pereira
